content:
Can someone check this out? https://github.com/majordwarf/zulip/tree/new-design

image.png
@Steve Howell @Tim Abbott @Yash RE ✨
The side-bar is now not so blocky. Added hover effect (some tweak needed for Night mode, still WIP), the checkbox are now toggle switches and everything is organized on either side.

Without commenting one way or the other on the design, I will point out that I was careful in #12597 to maintain the keyboard accessibility of these styled checkboxes by recreating the native focus rings, and you seem to have removed that.
Just based on the screenshot, have you thought about about styling the Headings a bit more differently to the contents eg centering the title / using HRs?

I understand the problem that the horizontal rules were meant to address, but they feel arbitrary here: usually horizontal rules indicate top-level groupings. Perhaps there are other ways to make it easy to associate the checkbox widgets with their labels—for example, the labels could be right-aligned within their column and the widgets could be left-aligned within theirs?
Do you mean like the hotkey help?
Yeah.
Also we need to make sure the design is responsive and works on thin browser widths for mobile web. (Maybe you already did this and just didn’t make a screenshot for this case.)
So, I kinda feel unhappy with what we did there with the text on that modal and honestly have been thinking that maybe we should consider changing it
the problem? I think it makes the user eye move in weird patterns, because the start point of the sentence varies...
but not sure, what do other folks think about that?
It’s also less necessary in hotkey help because the alternating background colors solve the association problem.
But left-aligning both columns might work too.
Hmm, can we at least center the headers in the new design for settings? I think that would help?

I worry that centering won’t work well visually in a design that doesn’t have things aligned with both margins, and I’m arguing against having things aligned with both margins. I guess it’s correlated with other decisions to be made.
For hotkey help maybe we could just swap the two columns. The other two tabs of that modal have the descriptions on the right side anyway.
I think that might suit "looking up the action for a key" better than "looking up the key that does an action" :/
thinking about this gives me icky feelings.
No, it’s exactly for “looking up the key that does an action”. Like you said, if you’re scanning for a given action, you want the column you’re scanning to be left-aligned.
(Of course this is LTR-biased. RTL languages probably want the opposite.)
Maybe I just can't imagine it as you do, but I don't think you'll ever see a legend (eg on a map) with the key on the right and the description on the left :/
I’m not sure if you wrote that the way you meant, but see Gmail’s keyboard shortcut help popup, and also our “Message formatting” and “Search operators” tabs.
oh.
Alright. I'm in favor of what you're suggesting.

Feedback to the screenshot:

  • Aligning labels left and inputs all the way to the right is horrible from an UX standpoint since your eyes need to travel a long way (see the blue lines in my screenshot) and it's easy to loose the current line, even with your borders.

  • I don't find the rounded border to be an improvement, especially since it introduces an ugly gap (highlighted in red in my screenshot). I think our current gapless squared active section highlighting looks better.

  • I am uncertain about the toggle buttons ... they feel more heavy compared to checkboxes. On desktop I think checkboxes are generally more common. It might make sense to switch to toggle buttons on mobile because of the bigger click area.

image.png
reference SC for what Anders Kaseorg and I were talking about:

@Gittenburg That space on the left sidebar is intentional.
@Yash RE ✨ That side-by-side is good for such application but for these, I guess on either side, left or right is appropriate. Also, you can click on labels to toggle.

Gittenburg said:

  • Aligning labels left and inputs all the way to the right is horrible from an UX standpoint since your eyes need to travel a long way (see the blue lines in my screenshot) and it's easy to loose the current line, even with your borders.
    image.png

So you disagree with this idea?
I have seen a lot of apps use it and don't see an issue there.
Do you have the dev server running?
I don't like the way we format the keyboard help. The left column is impossible to scan.
Not to mention that the left column isn't sorted.
@Tejas Tank this is a nit pick really, but it'd be really helpful if you could just open a wip PR if you'd like people to pull your branch and check it out.
We have specific tools like ./tools/fetch-rebase-pr that are conveniences
Yeah I've used that in past. Will make one, although it's still very much WIP
Thank you :)

Steve Howell said:

Not to mention that the left column isn't sorted.

Yep, sometimes such things looks weird things not starting at the same point.

Steve Howell said:

I don't like the way we format the keyboard help. The left column is impossible to scan.

May I file an issue? I don't want us to lose track of the complaints here. I think it's also clear what we want, so it'd be great for someone to pick up.
yeah, please so

Tejas Tank said:

I have seen a lot of apps use it and don't see an issue there.

That excessive distance between label and input hurts UX is well studied ... therefore pretty much every mainstream app avoids it ... we should too.
